content.webTitle: Animal Babies: First Year on Earth review – maximum adorableness!

fields.headline: Animal Babies: First Year on Earth review – maximum adorableness!
fields.bodyText: Great white sharks, feral dogs, lions and polluting, germ-carrying humans. And those are just the start of the perils facing the youngest animals in Animal Babies: First Year on Earth (BBC Two). The baby elephant has to contend with an irritated older brother attempting to kick it out of the way; the infant mountain gorilla has to be wary of rival silverbacks. They are so fragile, so vulnerable, it’s a wonder they survive. Many don’t, as we are often reminded. Half of the hyena cubs won’t live to see their first birthday and 60% of macaque babies don’t make it. But let’s not spoil it – this is uplifting, emotional telly with a soothing narration by the actor Wunmi Mosaku, in whose voice you can often hear a smile. If you’re the sort of person who wells up at One Born Every Minute (I am), you will find much to swell the heart here. In Kenya, a newborn elephant calf, Safina, skates on the mud, all wobbly legs – her mother scoots her along, trunk on bottom. The wildlife camerawoman, Sue Gibson, can’t contain her delight (as well as the baby animals, we meet three camera operators). “Poor little baby,” she says, laughing. “It’s so undignified.” They are social animals, “and survival depends on forming these bonds quickly”. Safina and another baby elephant cuddle each other with their trunks. Then there’s alarm as another herd approach, but it’s fine – it’s Safina’s aunt and the older elephants greet each other warmly, trunks embracing. “They really look like they’re happy to see each other,” says Gibson. It’s completely lovely. Next, we watch a clan of hyenas, where a dozen cubs have been born. Hyenas don’t tend to come off well in nature documentaries, but here they are adorable and fascinating. They live in a “female-led hierarchy” and the alpha female Soup has 12-week-old twin girls, Bisque and Chowder (even their names are cute). They squeak, mewl and follow their mother, learning their place in the hierarchy – this basically means nipping other cubs, including an older, bigger male. “It’s really great to see them with the other cubs,” says the thrilled cameraman Vianet Djenguet, “throwing their weight around.” But there’s danger everywhere: lions will attack hyenas, as will elephants. An elephant charges and the cubs run and hide. “I just have to remind myself that half of those cubs won’t make it,” says Djenguet. Spare a thought, too, for the baby southern sea otters picked off by great white sharks. Sharks don’t tend to eat otters, but they will have a nibble to see if it’s something they might like. And the otters are “too small to survive the wounds” – sharks are responsible for half of otter deaths. Here is a six-week-old sea otter, Limpet (so-called because he won’t leave his mother’s side; he must have an inkling that she plans to abandon him when he is six months old). If Limpet is going to survive, he must learn to dive. But he can’t at the moment because the air trapped in his dense juvenile fur – more hairs on each square centimetre than on an entire human head – is acting “like a little lifejacket”. Facts such as this stop the show, the first in a series, feeling like a wasted – if enjoyable – afternoon spent watching baby animal videos on the internet. In Sri Lanka, a tiny, hairless toque macaque, named Jazir, has been born to an alpha female. He clings – a tiny, wrinkled Sméagol – to his mother with little pink fingers. The great white shark equivalent here is lost habitat and its ills. “Where there are people, there are dogs,” we are told – and they hunt baby monkeys. There is a panicked moment when the dogs attack, but the mother makes it up the tree in time with Jazir clinging to her. In Uganda, the beautiful Nyakabara, snoozing with her mother, is one of possibly only 50 mountain gorilla babies in the world. These apes climb trees to get to fruit, even though gorillas are heavy (some weigh more than 180kg) and falls kill many. There’s a heart-stopping scene where Nyakabara has to cling to her mother, who is climbing a tree. Then – no! – the branch they are on snaps, and they plummet from view. It’s not until the next day that Djenguet and the conservation team track the family and find Nyakabara and her mother have survived. They disappear, baby still clinging on, into the trees. By the time we finish with some Arctic fox cubs emerging from their den in Iceland, I feel I have gorged on sweetness. They gambol, play fight and practise pouncing. The threat of doom is never far away – the summer is short and so is the food supply – so you can never truly relax into the adorableness of it all, but there is something so cheering about the babies’ determination and their mothers’ care. Normally, I find the personal observations of wildlife camera operators irritating, but it works here – mainly because delight is an emotion best shared. When the young sea otter takes his first dive, the proud cameraman Colin Stafford-Johnson says, “It’s almost like seeing your kid ride a bike for the first time.” When a baby female mountain gorilla beats her chest, mimicking the alpha male, Djenguet says, “You can’t get any better than that.” I think he may be right.
